executive_summary: The mattress manufacturing industry faced volatility during the pandemic. Early on, low interest rates and rising disposable income boosted demand from residential construction. However, later inflation, rate hikes, and economic uncertainty lowered housing demand, hurting mattress sales. Revenue fell at a 0.8% CAGR to $8.5 billion in 2024. Price competition, fluctuating input costs like steel, and imports hurt profitability. Manufacturers moved into e-commerce and direct-to-consumer sales. Consolidation occurred as top players acquired others. Looking ahead, an economic recovery, e-commerce growth, and improved materials/techniques should drive a 1.5% revenue CAGR to $9.1 billion by 2028 as large purchases rebound.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: New home purchases and moving spur mattress buying. The residential construction value, existing home sales, and housing starts indicate sector health and demand for manufacturers.
Large manufacturers adopted direct-to-consumer sales, seen as more convenient by consumers. This boosted sales.
Consumers opted for cheaper imported mattresses over pricier domestic ones, especially during the pandemic uncertainty. A strong US dollar made imports more affordable.
Volatile prices for inputs like steel and oil, especially after the pandemic, raised costs and squeezed profits for domestic manufacturers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Improving economic conditions like consumer confidence, income, and lower interest rates will spur large purchases like homes and mattresses.
E-commerce and direct-to-consumer will grow, benefiting manufacturers. But uncertain trade conditions could impact imports/exports.
Health-conscious consumers will buy high-end mattresses for better sleep. Demand for innovative products like specialty mattresses will rise.
New start-ups will emerge to produce innovative, high-end niche mattresses for wealthier consumers and export markets.

industry_definition: The Mattress Manufacturing industry produces mattresses and bases for retailers, wholesalers, hospitals, hotels and export markets. Products include innerspring, box spring, waterbeds, and foam/rubber/latex mattresses.
key_trends: The need for strong brand recognition makes it difficult for new mattress manufacturers to establish contracts with retailers.
Demand for low-cost imports is falling as consumer preferences shift. Consumers demand high-quality, innovative products as they increasingly focus on the importance of sleep quality.
Product innovation drove growth as consumer preferences shifted to high-quality mattresses. Companies innovated and created new products to remain competitive and differentiate themselves.
Direct-to-consumer sales will spur growth by offering customers convenience. E-commerce sales and companies operating their own retail outlets will drive growth.
Improving economic conditions and a recovering residential sector will boost demand for mattresses. As more consumers continue to move and purchase homes, the need for mattresses grows.

Stiff competition forces companies to focus on research and development to differentiate themselves. Sleep Number Corporation has more than doubled its research and development expenditure in recent years.
Large household names are dominant among mattress manufacturers. Tempur Sealy and Serta Simmons make up nearly three-quarters of industry revenue.

Significant import penetration has pushed the Federal government to support domestic manufacturers. The government aims to support producers through tariffs, which vary based on the material of the mattress.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Furniture stores offer mattresses as well as other furniture for homes. Sales within this segment have suffered in recent years because of the growing share of sales to specialty bedding stores and manufacturer-managed retail outlets.

Bedding stores specialize in retailing mattresses and complimentary bedding products like pillows and sheets. In recent years, specialty bedding stores have drawn a significant share of sales away from general furniture stores through distribution partnerships with mattress manufacturers, specialized staff and targeted advertising campaigns.

General retail, including department stores and discount retail stores, offer a smaller selection of mattresses than furniture or bedding stores; however, their prices tend to be competitive because of their size and purchasing power.
The accommodation sector includes hotels, which typically buy high-end and mid-range mattresses; motels, which purchase lower-end mattresses; and other hospitality companies.
Sales of mattresses to companies in the healthcare sector, which include hospital bed manufacturers, hospitals, nursing homes, healthcare professionals and medical supply retailers.
Manufacturers ship mattresses and other products directly to consumers through e-commerce platforms.

products_and_services.product_description: This type of mattress, which can come in all sizes and different firmness levels, uses the support of tempered steel coils in various configurations.
This segment includes foam mattresses, air beds, futons, waterbeds, and cribs for infants and toddlers.
This segment includes mattress covers, bases or underlays.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast is the preeminent mattress manufacturing region since it is both a major producer of cotton.
The West is a highly populated region that has access to major trade ports.
The Great Lakes region is a manufacturing hub.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The industry must comply with regulations that apply to the entire manufacturing sector.
Penalties are imposed on mattress manufacturers that violate United States labor and wage laws.
Manufacturers must properly label bedding merchandise to comply with regulation standards.
One of the newest regulations for this sector includes the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission's new standard on flame-retardant mattresses.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Companies must adhere to Occupational Safety and Health Administration standards for their workforce.
Setting up a mattress manufacturing business has high start-up costs.
Competition is high, with large established mattress manufacturers dominating the industry.
Compared with many other manufacturing industries, the industry is relatively labor-intensive.

basis_points.basis_description: The need for strong brand recognition makes it difficult for new mattress manufacturers to establish contracts with retailers.
Demand for low-cost imports is falling as consumer preferences shift.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Well-established manufacturers have existing relationships with major retailers.
Market share concentration has increased as large mattress manufacturers have been active in merger and acquisition activities.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: High-End Design and Production Swells Wages

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Other Costs Surge as New Technologies Rise
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The rise in popularity of e-commerce over the pandemic has enabled manufacturers to target consumers directly.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Compared with many other manufacturing industries, the industry is relatively labor-intensive.
Mattress manufacturers invest in research and development to satisfy demand for cutting edge sleep technology.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Mattress producers have been developing new materials
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Manufacturers have been increasingly focusing on making mattresses of materials that have other health-related benefits.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Adjustable mattresses enable customers to control the temperature, angle and firmness of their bedding.
Sleep-tracking mattresses automatically adjust aspects of positioning and airflow based on data collected on users' sleeping patterns.

FAQs.question: How is your company impacted by rising imports from abroad?
FAQs.answer: Increases in imported mattresses have been problematic for domestic mattress producers.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Mattress manufacturers do well when the economy is running strong.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Two main inputs to mattress manufacturing, crude oil and steel, have traditionally faced significant volatility.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in locations with well-established infrastructure networks?
FAQs.answer: Acquisitions are common among mattress manufacturers.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology in its operations?
FAQs.answer: Some companies manufacture conventional bedding to order and have adopted just-in-time inventory techniques.

FAQs.question: How has price volatility of inputs affected profit over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers are susceptible to inputs with volatile prices, such as steel and crude oil.

FAQs.question: How frequently does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Purchase costs, which include inputs such as wire coils, foam, plastic and paperboard containers, represent the largest expense for the industry.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets? Do you have plans to expand into other markets?
FAQs.answer: Due to the bulky nature of mattresses, manufacturers must be close to retailers and consumers.

FAQs.question: Do you have contracts with reliable input providers?
FAQs.answer: Access to high-quality, low-cost materials ensures that production of mattresses is not disrupted.

FAQs.question: Do you have access to the latest available and most efficient technology and techniques? How do you plan to further gain access to new technology?
FAQs.answer: Developing new manufacturing technology can help a company gain a competitive advantage.

FAQs.question: How do you track changes in the trade-weighted index?
FAQs.answer: The trade-weighted index (TWI) measures the strength of the US dollar in relation to the currencies of the nation's trading partners.

FAQs.question: How have changes in e-commerce sales affected your business? What are some methods you can use to better compete with online sales?
FAQs.answer: As e-commerce sales continue to rise, this poses an opportunity for manufacturers.

FAQs.question: During times of low disposable income, what are your best-selling products? How do you mitigate costs when per capita disposable income fluctuates?
FAQs.answer: Increases in household disposable income generally lead to higher mattress sales.
